title: German green energy marketers eye storage opportunities – poll
subtitle: (Montel) German green energy marketing portfolios grew last year, with Quadra Energy replacing ENBW as the market leader, while companies were eyeing further growth opportunities in the field with the rise of battery storage, Montel’s annual survey found.
body:
Quadra Energy, which was acquired by French energy company TotalEnergies in 2023, saw its portfolio increase by 900 MW to 10,400 MW last year, while utility ENBW’s portfolio shrank by 207 MW to 9,350 MW.
As of 1 January, the third largest portfolio was held by renewable energy marketer Next Kraftwerke with 8,475 MW.
Utility Engie Germany, meanwhile, recorded the largest growth in capacity volume year on year – growing 2,300 MW to 5,288 MW – and ranked eighth amongst the country’s green power marketers in 2024.
“Pleasing growth”“We are seeing pleasing growth in our portfolio. It is the strongest increase in our seven-year history of direct marketing in Germany,” said Tobias Heyen, head of origination at Engie Germany.
The boost came, with many survey respondents pointing to the potential of battery storage and other flexibility options to complement the growth of intermittent renewables output.
“The marketing of BESS [battery energy storage systems] and other controllable plants such as biogas and CHP [combined heat and power] plants and electrolysers is a growth area for us,” said Nicole Teschauer of green firm BaywaRe.
“Biogas plants, conventional plants and batteries have the ability to produce or store electricity flexibly. Therefore, the expansion plays a central role in our business in the coming years,” said Anne Walter of Leipzig-based direct marketer Energy to Market.
Challenging conditionsHowever, despite the overall positive trend in marketing volumes, participants faced challenging market conditions last year, particularly in the power purchase agreement (PPA) sector, said those surveyed.
“Last year was mainly characterised by a sharp increase in negative prices. Here, the good controllability of PV [photovoltaic] systems is a key factor in addressing this phenomenon, which will intensify with further expansion,” said Lotte Lehmbruck, head of communication and market research at Next Kraftwerke.
Negative prices are a growing phenomenon, particularly at times of low demand and high renewables output.
“Systems that are not well controllable will increasingly struggle to find marketing under acceptable conditions,” added Lehmbruck.
“Electricity prices have now fallen back to a level that makes concluding PPAs with electricity prices above common subsidy rates for PV and onshore wind almost impossible,” said Thomas Krings, managing director of Quadra Energy, noting off-takers did not want to be locked into PPAs amid lower wholesale power prices.
The expansion of solar capacity by around 30 GW in the past two years had also drastically reduced the value of such units, he added.
Switch of focus“Driven mainly by this expansion, we have already seen almost 500 hours with negative prices this year [2024] alone. That’s more than 5% of all delivery hours,” Krings said, with Quadra now switching its focus to wind energy plants in the PPA segment
In terms of a wishlist for the next government ahead of next month’s general election, survey respondents were largely in agreement on the need for simpler regulation governing direct marketing.
“Further deregulation by reducing regulatory requirements and processes… would be desirable,” said Regina Wolter, spokeswoman from utility RWE.
Germany’s direct marketing scheme grants renewables operators a premium on top of the wholesale price of power if they sell their production directly to market instead of through TSOs, which are otherwise obliged to pay fixed tariffs. Marketers can also manage portfolios on behalf of other green producers.
